I think this issue stems more from the habit of using JUnit as an
acceptance or interaction testing framework rather than just a unit
testing framework.
 
As far as unit tests go, I am 110% with you.  However, the design of
JUnit has made it extremely simple to use for the other two types of
testing I referred to.  That being said, I don't believe this request
should be embodied in JUnit-proper.  Let it be an add-on feature.  I
would even argue to remove TestSetup once people get used to using
Vladimir's Add-Ons project in SourceForge (or sooner, since most folks
won't embrace change without some force to move them from their current
path -- the 2nd law of thermodynamics I believe).
 
=jason

--- In junit@y..., "David Vydra" <yahoogroups@v...> wrote:
> I would like to get the group's opinion about adding setUp() and 
> tearDown() methods to the TestSuite class. I think it has several 
> advantages:
> 
> 1. It makes it similar to TestCase
> 2. It makes it easier for QA engineers, who may not feel 
comfortable 
> with a decorator like TestSetup (no offense meant to QA engineers 
who 
> do)
> 3. Sometimes you need to access the suite in the composite after 
it 
> was wrapped in TestSetup.

The first design principle of xUnit (good or bad) is independence of 
tests. TestSetup is a step away from that, which I regret. The need 
for shared setup is IME always a design problem. Solving it by 
writing tests differently is the first step on a slippery slope to 
making the tests less valuable to programmers.

Kent
